description:
Orussus abietinus is a species of parasitoid wasp belonging to the family Orussidae. It is a small insect, typically measuring between 5-10 millimeters in length.

The species is known to parasitize the larvae of wood-boring beetles, particularly those that infest coniferous trees such as spruce, fir, and pine. The female wasp uses its long, slender ovipositor to deposit her eggs directly into the host larva, typically within the tree's wood.

Once the Orussus abietinus egg hatches, the wasp larva will feed on the host larva, eventually killing it and emerging as an adult wasp. This process allows the Orussus abietinus to complete its life cycle and ensure the survival of the next generation.

The species is found throughout Europe and parts of Asia, where it plays a role in the natural regulation of wood-boring beetle populations in forest ecosystems. Its unique parasitoid lifestyle and adaptations to its host species make Orussus abietinus an interesting subject of study for researchers in the fields of entomology and forest ecology.
